title: Customer Readiness Level 9
body: The product/service is widely deployed with repeatable and scalable sales to several customers, often also through partners. There is a large and strongly growing base of active users (strong traction), and the company is heavily focused on business development, customer acquisition, sales growth and building user/customer demand.

title: Customer Readiness Level 8
body: A market-ready product/service is sold to customers at or near the target market price, with a substantial number of active users (initial traction). A formal sales/user acquisition process exists with dedicated people and support systems (e.g. CRM), and agreements with initial partners are in place to reach customers.

title: Customer Readiness Level 7
body: Customer agreements exist for first sales or test sales of early versions, or customers/users are engaged in product/service qualification or extended testing, and there is a small but active user base of these early versions. Discussions with partners to help reach customers/users have been initiated where relevant.

title: Customer Readiness Level 6
body: Customer/user testing has confirmed the value and benefits of the product/service, leading to an updated sales pitch and value proposition based on their feedback. A first sales/user acquisition process is defined, structured sales activities have started, and potential partners or key stakeholders to reach customers/users have been identified.

title: Customer Readiness Level 5
body: Customers/users have clearly expressed interest and confirmed that the product/service can solve their problems/needs, indicating an initial problem–solution fit. Relationships with potential target customers/users provide input, target customer segments have been prioritised, and an initial sales pitch and value proposition tailored to these segments is defined.

title: Customer Readiness Level 4
body: The problem/need and its importance are confirmed by multiple customers or users (typically 5–10 in B2B, 2–5 leading customers in concentrated B2B markets, or around 10–20 in B2C). Basic customer segmentation and profiles exist, the user, paying customer and decision maker are identified, and a product/service hypothesis is positioned clearly against alternatives based on customer/user feedback.

title: Customer Readiness Level 3
body: Primary market research (direct contact with a few potential users/customers or industry/market experts) has provided feedback. There is now a better understanding of possible customers and segments, and the problem/need hypothesis is clearly stated and has been refined using this feedback.

title: Customer Readiness Level 2
body: Some market research has been conducted, mainly from secondary sources, giving brief familiarity with the market, potential customers, their problems/needs and existing alternatives. A first reasonably clear description of the problem/need hypothesis has been formulated.

title: Customer Readiness Level 1
body: You are mainly thinking yourself that a potential need/problem or opportunity might exist in a market, without external validation. There are no clear hypotheses about customers or problems (or they are vague and speculative with no supporting proof or analysis), and knowledge of the market and customers/users is very limited or non-existent.

title: Technology Readiness Level 9
body: The complete technology is scalable and has been proven to work in actual operations by several users over time. Continuous development, improvement and optimisation of both the technology and its production are ongoing.

title: Technology Readiness Level 8
body: A complete technology has been proven to work in actual operations by first users: it includes everything the user needs, functions correctly, is compatible with people, processes, goals, infrastructure and systems, and is producible at reasonable cost. It meets all performance requirements/specifications and is implemented independently by end-users in their day-to-day operations.

title: Technology Readiness Level 7
body: A prototype close to or at the final technology has been shown to work in an operational environment, i.e. one that addresses all operational requirements and specifications where end-users will actually use it. Complete end-user requirements/specifications and/or use cases are in place.

title: Technology Readiness Level 6
body: A representative model or prototype of the technology has been shown to work in a relevant environment, using a functional form (often scaled or near/at operational spec) that allows evaluation of technical and/or manufacturing feasibility and utility of the final product. This demonstration meets most important performance requirements.

title: Technology Readiness Level 5
body: Basic components are integrated and tested in a more realistic form in a relevant environment, such as a lab or controlled setting that simulates the most important and most stressing aspects of the real operational environment. Test results validate that the technology will work and more detailed end-user requirements/specifications and/or use cases are defined based on user feedback.

title: Technology Readiness Level 4
body: Basic components are integrated and shown to work together to produce the desired results in a laboratory environment. Test results give initial validation that the technology concept will work.

title: Technology Readiness Level 3
body: In a laboratory environment (the analytical/experimental setting where the technology is typically developed, often different from the final use environment), tests of important parameters, features and functions show that the technology concept could work and be feasible. Active R&D is underway to develop the technology further, and a first idea of end-user requirements/specifications and/or use cases exists.

title: Technology Readiness Level 2
body: A potential technology concept is defined and described. Practical applications can be outlined or researched but remain speculative, with no proof or detailed analysis yet that the technology will work.

title: Technology Readiness Level 1
body: Research results indicate potential benefits or useful applications. There is only a vague idea of the technology to be developed.

title: Business Readiness Level 9
body: The business model is fully operational and proven, with the business meeting or exceeding expectations on profit, growth and scalability, while actively pursuing additional target markets with an internationalization strategy. Competitor monitoring is expanded to cover new markets and future scenarios, and operations, growth and sustainability are balanced and validated through sustainability metrics.

title: Business Readiness Level 8
body: Sales and other metrics show the business model is viable in terms of profit and growth, and future additional target markets (including international ones) are clearly described. Continuous competitor monitoring is implemented, and sustainability is integrated into the business as a driver of business value and positive impact.

title: Business Readiness Level 7
body: The business model is validated by first commercial sales to several customers, and target markets plus sales estimates are confirmed by market feedback. Market differentiators/USPs are validated and used in marketing and communication, and sustainability metrics (including how to monitor and report them) are defined.

title: Business Readiness Level 6
body: Target customers have validated the business model in realistic business scenarios such as pilots, test sales or pre-orders, and the first target market (including geographic focus) is chosen based on market input. Key market differentiators/USPs are defined and included in pitches/presentations, while key sustainability metrics (e.g. carbon footprint, social impact, circularity) are proposed.

title: Business Readiness Level 5
body: Key assumptions of the business model, especially willingness to pay and pricing, are validated by market feedback, and target market descriptions are refined based on this feedback, including the venture’s own position in the value chain. The company updates its positioning in the competitive landscape and considers how sustainability can be integrated to achieve a positive impact.

title: Business Readiness Level 4
body: Initial calculations of main costs and revenues (including pricing) indicate possible economic viability, and potential target markets are well defined with TAM, SAM, SOM, value chain and geographic scope. The business has suggested its own position in the competitive landscape and carried out an SDG assessment outlining both positive and negative impacts.

title: Business Readiness Level 3
body: A draft business model is documented (e.g. in a canvas), with a first description of possible target markets and estimates of their size (TAM, SAM). The competitive landscape is described (e.g. via matrix or positioning map), and there is an initial description of which SDG(s) the business could address.

title: Business Readiness Level 2
body: The business concept is described in a structured way (e.g. value proposition such as NABC), with an initial overview of markets and their potential size. Some competitors and/or alternative solutions are listed, and there is some early insight into why and how sustainability aspects relate to the business.

title: Business Readiness Level 1
body: There is only a vague or unspecified description of the business idea, value proposition and business model, with little understanding of the market, its size or potential. Knowledge of competitors or alternatives is minimal, and there is little to no awareness of how sustainability aspects could affect the business idea.

title: Intellectual Property Readiness Level 9
body: The IPR strategy is proven to support and create business value, with key and complementary IPR granted and maintained in several relevant countries. All needed external IPR is secured through agreements.

title: Intellectual Property Readiness Level 8
body: The IPR strategy is fully implemented: IPR is actively used to support/protect the business, agreements are professionally managed, and there is a clear process for securing new IPR. Key IPR is granted in the first relevant country/region and complementary or additional IPR applications/registrations have been filed.

title: Intellectual Property Readiness Level 7
body: Key IPR has entered the national/regional phase (e.g. US, EU, JP) with active applications/registrations. A more complete freedom-to-operate assessment has been done, with clear understanding of dependencies on or restrictions by other IPR.

title: Intellectual Property Readiness Level 6
body: A complete IPR strategy, validated by a professional, is in place and aligned with the business strategy, including identified complementary/additional IPR to protect. An initial freedom-to-operate analysis maps the IPR landscape (who is active, key rights, dependence/ blocking risks), and authority responses to applications are analysed with a professional to confirm good prospects or adapt if needed.

title: Intellectual Property Readiness Level 5
body: A draft IPR strategy exists, including a first professional analysis and plan for how different IPR can protect and add value to the business. The first full application/registration for key IPR is filed with professional support, and basic agreements (assignments, ownership, etc.) ensure control over this key IPR.

title: Intellectual Property Readiness Level 4
body: Professional searches/analysis confirm that protection of key IPR is possible, and the key IPR plus priorities for what to protect to create business value are analysed (ideally with a professional). A first IPR application/registration may be filed in a simpler form, such as self-filed trademark or provisional patent.

title: Intellectual Property Readiness Level 3
body: The team has considered which forms of IPR are most important and should be protected, and described possible IPR in enough detail to judge protectability. Protection options are evaluated via own searches of publications and state-of-the-art solutions, with possible initial professional checks for prior art or conflicting IPR.

title: Intellectual Property Readiness Level 2
body: Different possible forms of IPR that exist or could arise during development are mapped, and some specific IPR ideas exist but are still vague and not well defined. IP-related agreements and ownership (including inventors/creators) are clarified, along with awareness of relevant IP policies and potential contractual restrictions.

title: Intellectual Property Readiness Level 1
body: There is only a hypothesis that results or ideas might contain some form of IPR and some speculative ideas about what that IPR could be. The possible IPR is not described or documented, and knowledge of legal aspects (ownership, use-rights, etc.), uniqueness, and the technical/state-of-the-art landscape is very limited.

title: Team Readiness Level 9
body: The organization is high-performing and well-functioning, with strong cooperation and a good social environment. All levels are engaged in continuous learning and development, culture/structure/processes are continuously improved, incentives and rewards motivate the whole organization to reach goals, and the management team is maintained, developed and consistently performs over time.

title: Team Readiness Level 8
body: There is a clear leadership and management team with relevant professional experience, supported by a competent and diverse board and advisors that are actively used. HR policies, processes and roles ensure good HR practices and team diversity, planned recruitments are underway to secure needed competencies, capacity and diversity, and all levels of the organization are well trained and motivated.

title: Team Readiness Level 7
body: The team is well-functioning with clear roles, and goals, vision, purpose and culture are clearly articulated and documented to support team and organizational development. There is a plan to build the necessary organization and grow the team over the longer term (~2 years), processes/systems for continuous learning and staff development are implemented, and the board and advisors are operational and support both business and organizational development.

title: Team Readiness Level 6
body: A complementary and diverse founding team is in place and capable of starting to build the business, with all near-term key competencies and capacity covered, including a clear CEO. The team is committed with shared responsibility and accountability, recruitment of advisors/board members (with attention to diversity) has started, and there is awareness of risks to team performance such as conflicts, burnout/mental health and politics.

title: Team Readiness Level 5
body: An initial founding team works together, all spending significant time and jointly holding the main competencies and capacity needed to start building the startup, with clarified roles, shared goals/visions and clear commitment (e.g. time spent). The team has a signed ownership-shares agreement that is balanced, incentivizing and reflects past and future contributions, is actively working to add further competencies and capacity with diversity in mind, and has initial systems/processes/tools to share knowledge and information.

title: Team Readiness Level 4
body: The team (or individual) has a clear idea of how to bring the idea to market (e.g. startup, IP deal) and at least one committed champion driving it forward. Several, though not all, necessary competencies are present across multiple individuals, a plan has been initiated to find needed additional competencies and capacity (e.g. via a requirement profile) with attention to diversity, and the team has begun discussions on roles, commitment and ownership going forward.

title: Team Readiness Level 3
body: One or several individuals possess some, but not all, of the competencies and capacity needed to start verifying the idea. Needs and gaps in competencies, capacity and team diversity are identified, and an initial near-term (<1 year) plan exists for how to find the prioritized missing competencies.

title: Team Readiness Level 2
body: Only limited competencies and/or capacity are present (typically 1–2 people), with a first idea of which additional persons/competencies will be needed to verify and develop the idea. There is also a first idea of the overall goal for the project.

title: Team Readiness Level 1
body: Typically a single individual is involved who lacks necessary competencies in key areas such as technology and business. There is little insight into which competencies and other resources (e.g. partners, service providers) are needed to properly verify and develop the idea.

title: Sustainability Readiness Level 9
body: The company’s sustainability work has clear, measurable benefits where positive effects outweigh negative ones, and the overall system effects (outputs and outcomes) are well defined and communicable. Sustainability opportunities and risks are fully embedded in company culture, and suppliers/partners are chosen from a sustainability perspective.

title: Sustainability Readiness Level 8
body: Operational planning integrates relevant long-term standards (e.g. ISO 14001, 9001, 26000) to support credibility and development of the business. Sales and other metrics show the business model is both viable and sustainable (e.g. customer acquisition costs), and sustainability impacts (positive and negative) are communicated transparently to stakeholders.

title: Sustainability Readiness Level 7
body: Sustainability information that helps customers make purchase decisions is communicated transparently, and a baseline impact measurement is established to monitor and report created impact. Supplier requirements (e.g. code of conduct) are documented and validated, sustainability reporting routines are integrated into follow-up activities, and a regular “sanity check” confirms that sustainability benefits outweigh related costs and negative effects.

title: Sustainability Readiness Level 6
body: Objectives, internal and external metrics and actions for sustainability are validated and embedded in business plans (strategy, action plan, roadmap). The company has validated insights into both the benefits/values and the possible negative consequences for customers/users, and acts on sustainability-related KPIs that reduce risks and increase positive effects for them.

title: Sustainability Readiness Level 5
body: Relevant sustainability areas are identified and prioritised by impact, with associated business opportunities and risks clearly defined. Objectives, potential metrics and actions for sustainability are developed and integrated into business plans, and an initial draft of economic, social and ecological outputs/outcomes is formulated and tested with potential customers and partners.

title: Sustainability Readiness Level 4
body: There is initial stakeholder and supplier verification of the hypothesis about both positive and negative social and environmental impacts of the proposed product, business concept and activities in the intended ecosystem. Storytelling about sustainability and Agenda 2030, based on customer verification, is linked to the business concept and can be communicated to stakeholders.

title: Sustainability Readiness Level 3
body: The team’s sustainability competences and the company’s business approach are described, and a draft “Why”/mission outlines what the company aims to achieve in sustainability terms. A draft sustainable business model and sustainable value proposition are evaluated against the market and identified competitors’ offerings.

title: Sustainability Readiness Level 2
body: First customer verification of the hypothesis about both positive and negative social and environmental impacts of the product, business concept and activities has been carried out. There is some understanding of the benefits of a sustainable business model and a formulated hypothesis covering these positive and negative impacts for stakeholders.

title: Sustainability Readiness Level 1
body: The team has little or no knowledge of Agenda 2030 and sustainable development, and limited insight into the benefits of a sustainable business model. There is only a vague or absent idea of how sustainability could be integrated to address the problem the proposed business and operations should solve.

title: Funding Readiness Level 9
body: Next funding needs are clearly defined based on scale-up plans, company performance, and financial forecasts, with a long-term funding strategy for scaling operations in place. Suitable next-step funding sources have expressed firm interest for an extended runway, and the pitch/presentation, business plan and all supporting material are continuously updated.

title: Funding Readiness Level 8
body: Financial monitoring and accounting systems give control over current financial status and future funding needs, and the funding roadmap is updated according to forecasts and business progress. Funding is secured for at least ~12 months of runway (or via predictable recurring revenue), and the funding presentation includes the complete business plan.

title: Funding Readiness Level 7
body: Basic accounting provides a clear view of financial status and outlines different funding-need scenarios, while the funding roadmap details target sources over time plus backup alternatives. There are concrete term-sheet-level discussions with clearly interested funders, and the pitch includes all necessary supporting material to pass due diligence.

title: Funding Readiness Level 6
body: Funding needs are clarified with detailed financial projections, including cash-flow, and the funding roadmap is updated based on feedback and extended over multiple rounds (e.g. seed, Series A). Discussions have started with relevant funding sources (typically investors) about amounts, purpose and valuation, and the funding pitch has been improved based on feedback from relevant audiences.

title: Funding Readiness Level 5
body: Funding needs over time are outlined with initial financial projections (P&L, budget), and a possible funding roadmap with preferred funding sources/investors and their impact on the cap table is defined. Some additional funding for next development steps may be secured, though more is needed for later stages, and the pitch has been tested on relevant audiences (e.g. investors or submitted applications).

title: Funding Readiness Level 4
body: A development/project plan for about 6–12 months is defined with cost budget, key risks and value-driving milestones, and relevant funding sources for the next stages are identified. Enough funding is secured to initiate at least the first steps of the plan, and a formal funding pitch/presentation (oral and written, such as a pitch deck or application) is in place.

title: Funding Readiness Level 3
body: A draft development/project plan (6–12 months) with costs and activities provides insight into overall funding needs, and there is an understanding of main funding options, their types (own, soft, equity, loans) and requirements. Sufficient soft funding (typically grants) is secured for initial validation, and a first funding presentation describing key aspects such as market potential has been prepared.

title: Funding Readiness Level 2
body: There is some insight into the costs and activities needed for initial validation (about 1–6 months), and funding sources for this phase have been identified with efforts underway to secure them. A basic description of the business concept (e.g. NABC) exists that can be used to seek initial funding.

title: Funding Readiness Level 1
body: The team has little insight into the costs, activities and overall funding needs for validating the idea, and little understanding of different funding options. No funding is available or secured, and only an initial idea description exists that lacks key funding-relevant aspects such as a clear business concept and market potential.
